data.question: Can you provide practice problems on multiplying two matrices?

docs.title: 674dcdb4b00b977d048c931b
docs.text: The admission tickets to the Singapore Zoo are $50 for an adult, $36 for a child, and $20 for a senior citizen. On a particular Tuesday, there were 212 adults, 251 children, and 15 senior citizens who visited the Singapore Zoo and on a particular Wednesday, there were 231 adults, 266 children, and 12 senior citizens who visited the Singapore Zoo. The number of visitors on the particular Tuesday and Wednesday can be represented by the matrix V = \begin{pmatrix} 212 & 251 & 15 \\ 231 & 266 & 12 \end{pmatrix}. \text{ (i) Write a } 3 \times 1 \text{ matrix, P, to represent the price of the admission tickets. (ii) Find the matrix } T = VP. \text{ (iii) Explain what each of the elements represents. (iv) Find the total amount collected from the sales of the tickets for the 2 days.}

docs.title: 674dcde1b00b977d048c9352
docs.text: Two outlets of a coffee chain sell three different types of coffee: espresso, flat white and mocha. The table shows the number of cups of each type of coffee sold on a particular day. Outlet A: Espresso 30, Flat White 30, Mocha 35; Outlet B: Espresso x, Flat White x + 2, Mocha 40. This information can be represented by the matrix \( P = \begin{pmatrix} 30 & 30 & 35 \\ x & x+2 & 40 \end{pmatrix} \). The coffee chain sells a cup of espresso at $2.50, a cup of flat white at $4 and a cup of mocha at $5.50. This information can be represented by the matrix \( Q = \begin{pmatrix} 2.5 \\ 4 \\ 5.5 \end{pmatrix} \). (a) Find, in terms of x, the matrix \( R = PQ \).

By using matrix multiplication, calculate the total amount of money the dance school earns for this 10-week block of sessions.

data.output: A theater sells tickets for three different types of seating: VIP, regular, and balcony. The prices for these seats are $120, $75, and $50, respectively. On Tuesday, the theater sold 175 VIP seats, 220 regular seats, and 150 balcony seats. On Wednesday, 160 VIP seats, 245 regular seats, and 165 balcony seats were sold. Represent the sales for Tuesday and Wednesday with the matrix \( S = \begin{pmatrix} 175 & 220 & 150 \\ 160 & 245 & 165 \end{pmatrix} \). (i) Construct a \( 3 \times 1 \) matrix \( P \) to represent the price of each type of seating. (ii) Calculate the matrix \( T = SP \). (iii) Explain the significance of each element of \( T \). (iv) Compute the total revenue generated from ticket sales across the two days.

data.output:
A performing arts theatre charges $60 for adults, $40 for students, and $25 for children for their events. One week, they have performances on Friday and Saturday. On Friday, 150 adults, 180 students, and 30 children attend, while on Saturday, 200 adults, 220 students, and 50 children attend. Represent the number of attendees on each day using the matrix \( A = \begin{pmatrix} 150 & 180 & 30 \\ 200 & 220 & 50 \end{pmatrix} \). 

(i) Write a \( 3 \times 1 \) matrix, \( P \), to represent the prices of tickets. 
(ii) Calculate the matrix \( T = AP \). 
(iii) Interpret each element of \( T \). 
(iv) Determine the total revenue generated from both days combined.

data.output: A ticketing company sells tickets to a theatre play. The tickets are priced differently for three categories: VIP at $150, Regular at $60, and Economy at $35. On the opening night, 120 VIP tickets, 250 Regular tickets, and 180 Economy tickets were sold. On the closing night, the company sold 140 VIP tickets, 300 Regular tickets, and 220 Economy tickets. Represent the sales for these two nights in a matrix \( S = \begin{pmatrix} 120 & 250 & 180 \\ 140 & 300 & 220 \end{pmatrix} \). (i) Write a \( 3 \times 1 \) matrix, \( P \), to represent the ticket prices. (ii) Calculate the matrix \( T = SP \). (iii) Explain what each element of the resulting matrix \( T \) represents. (iv) Compute the total revenue collected from ticket sales over the two nights.

On market day 2, vendors sold 130 units of cheese, 190 units of bread, and 60 units of honey. Represent these sales using the matrix \( S = \begin{pmatrix} 120 & 200 & 50 \\ 130 & 190 & 60 \end{pmatrix} \). data.output:
A high school plans a two-day excursion to a technology exhibition. The entry fees are $40 for instructors, $30 for college students, and $15 for high school students. On the first day of the excursion, the group includes 150 instructors, 320 college students, and 180 high school students. On the second day, there are 170 instructors, 305 college students, and 190 high school students attending. Represent the number of attendees on both days with the matrix:
\[A = \begin{pmatrix} 150 & 320 & 180 \\ 170 & 305 & 190 \end{pmatrix}\]
(i) Write a 3x1 matrix \( F \) to represent the entry fees. (ii) Find the matrix \( C = AF \). (iii) Interpret the meaning of each element of matrix \( C \). (iv) Determine the total revenue collected from the excursion over the two days.
